required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparing the Ketogenic Effect of Coconut Oil and Different MCTs
clinical_study.official_title: Comparing the Ketogenic Effect of Coconut Oil and Different Medium-chain Triglycerides

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to compare the ketogenic effect of coconut oil and three MCT oils (60-40 , tricaprylin and triheptanoate) on the production of ketones in healthy adults. Each oil are evaluated individually or in combination over a 8h-period during which repeated blood sampling is performed.

detailed_description.textblock: The study is composed of eight successive visits. Each visit consists of the consumption of one individual oil or a mixture of oils (20 g of coconut oil or 10 g of coconut oil + 10 g of MCT 60-40 or 20 g MCT 60-40 or 10 g coconut oil + 10 g tricaprylin or 20 g tricaprylin or 10 g coconut oil + 10 g triheptanoate or 20 g triheptanoate) and a 8h follow-up during which repeated blood samples are taken for laboratory analysis (plasma beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, glucose, free fatty acids, triglycerides, total cholesterol, lactate and insulin).

primary_outcome.description: Total ketones = Plasma acetoacetate (µmol/L) + beta-hydroxybutyrate (µmol/L) measured over a 8 hour period (i.e. daily mean). Samples are taken every 30 minutes on a 8 hours period. The mean is reported here.

secondary_outcome.description: Plasma ratio of acetoacetate (µmol/L)/ beta-hydroxybutyrate (µmol/L) measured over a 8 hour period (i.e area-under-the-curve over 8 hours).

arm_group.description: Protocol involved seven separate but identical metabolic study days for each participant. the test substances were evaluated in random order: vehicle (Control) or 20 mL of the test oils (Coconut oil; tricaprin; tricaprylin; MCT [tricaprylin/tricaprin]; coconut oil + MCT [50:50]; Coconut oil + tricaprylin [50:50]) taken twice, once at breakfast and once at mid-day.

intervention.description: 10 g of coconut oil + 10 g of MCT (60 of C8 + 40 of C10)
20 g of MCT (60 of C8+40 of C10)
No supplement taken on this visit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy adult over 18 y old.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Fasting plasma glucose ≥7.0 mM (diabetics or pre-diabetics);
- Smoking
- Clinically-significant gastro-intestinal disease/conditions.
- Clinically-significant liver disease/dysfunction.
- Clinically-significant cardiac disease/conditions.
- Clinically-significant abnormal coagulation.
- Taking a medication that could affect lipid and glucose metabolism
- Hypertension
- Pregnancy or breastfeeding
- Exercising more than 3 times a week

overall_official.affiliation: CSSS-IUGS - CIUSSS de L'Estrie - CHUS - Université de Sherbrooke

facility.name: Research Centre on Aging (CSSS-IUGS - CIUSSS de l'Estrie - CHUS)

group.description: Protocol involved seven separate but identical metabolic study days for each participant. the test substances were evaluated in random order: vehicle (Control) or 20 mL of the test oils (Coconut oil; tricaprin; tricaprylin; MCT [tricaprylin/tricaprin]; coconut oil + MCT [50:50]; Coconut oil + tricaprylin [50:50]) taken twice, once at breakfast and once at mid-day. measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

outcome.title: Plasma Ketone Concentrations
outcome.description: Total ketones = Plasma acetoacetate (µmol/L) + beta-hydroxybutyrate (µmol/L) measured over a 8 hour period (i.e. daily mean). Samples are taken every 30 minutes on a 8 hours period. The mean is reported here.

group.description: 20 mL of Coconut oil + tricaprylin [50:50]) taken twice, once at breakfast and once at mid-day. Coconut oil + tricaprylin: 10 g coconut oil + 10 g tricaprylin

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
